case_vignette: A 36-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a painless lump on her neck for 3 months that has increased in size. She appears healthy. Examination shows a 2.5-cm (1-in) firm, irregular swelling on the left side of the neck that moves with swallowing. There is painless cervical lymphadenopathy. Ultrasound of the neck shows a solitary left lobe thyroid mass with increased vascularity and hyperechogenic punctate regions. A fine needle aspiration biopsy is scheduled for the following week.
question: Which  is the most likely diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Endocrinology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask simple 1 line questions, one question at a time. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I have a painless lump on my neck that has gotten bigger over the last three months.
How old are you and what is your sex?
I am a 36-year-old woman.
Have you had any changes in your voice or difficulty swallowing?
No, I haven't had any changes in my voice or difficulty swallowing.
Have you experienced any weight changes, heat or cold intolerance, or changes in your energy levels recently?
I appear healthy and haven't mentioned any symptoms related to weight, temperature intolerance, or energy levels.
Do you have any family history of thyroid disease or autoimmune conditions?
The information about my family history of thyroid disease or autoimmune conditions hasn't been provided.
Is the lump on your neck located in the area around your Adam's apple, slightly below it, or elsewhere?
The lump is on the left side of my neck.
Do you have any other lumps or swelling anywhere else on your body?
I have painless swollen lymph nodes in my neck.
Have you noticed any fever, night sweats, or unintentional weight loss?
I haven't mentioned experiencing fever, night sweats, or unintentional weight loss.
Do you currently take any medications or have any other existing health conditions?
I haven't mentioned taking any medications or having other health conditions.
Have you experienced any recent infections or illnesses?
I haven't mentioned any recent infections or illnesses.
Have you had any prior imaging studies or biopsies done on the lump?
An ultrasound of my neck was performed.
Were there any findings from the ultrasound that you can share?
The ultrasound showed a single mass in the left side of my thyroid gland with increased blood flow and tiny bright spots inside it.
Final Diagnosis: Thyroid nodule, possible thyroid adenoma or carcinoma.

trial_0.summarized_conversation: A 36-year-old woman presents with a painless lump on the left side of her neck that has been increasing in size over the past three months. She has no changes in voice or difficulty swallowing and appears overall healthy. There is no mention of any symptoms related to weight, temperature intolerance, or energy levels, and no information about family history of thyroid disease or autoimmune conditions. The patient also has painless swollen lymph nodes in her neck, but denies experiencing fever, night sweats, or unintentional weight loss. The patient has not reported taking any medications, having other health conditions, recent infections, or illnesses. An ultrasound of the neck revealed a single mass in the left side of the thyroid gland with increased blood flow and tiny bright spots inside it.
